Panel Name

fwElmbDiConfigOperation.pnl
Introduction
 This panel is used for the operational setup of the Digital Input port(s) for a selected ELMB that has been created in the current system. Some other information regarding the ELMB is also available from this panel.
Instructions The different controls for the panel (Figure 1) are described below:

Firmware

The three fields here are read only fields. The information is set into the text fields when the information is read from the ELMB. You cannot alter these values. They show the:

Software version - In some cases (depending on the version) a 'sub-version' may also be displayed

Hardware version - The hardware version is displayed

Serial Number - In most cases (apart from very old ELMBs) the serial number of the ELMB is displayed. If this information is not held in the ELMB, the text 'N/A' will be displayed (as it is Non-Applicable).

Debounce timer

Here you may select a value for the debounce timer. This timer enters a delay between successive polls of the digital inputs. The values are in units of approximately 0.5ms.

Global Digital Input Interrupt Enable

This enables or disables the change-of-state transmission of digital inputs. If enabled, any change of state of a single (or multiple) digital input line will cause a message to be sent from the ELMB with the new value of the digital inputs.

Digital Input Transmission Type

Here you can select whether the ELMB responds to a SYNC message (by then sending the values of all the analog and digital inputs) or to an RTR (Remote Transmission Request). If 'After RTR message' is selected, you may also enter a value for the Event Timer by selecting from the drop-down list. If the value for the Event Timer is greater than zero, then the ELMB sends all the values of analog and digital inputs at the selected time interval.

Read and Write

Read - Clicking the button labeled 'Read' causes the OPC Server to request all the information from the ELMB that may be displayed in the panel. If successful, all values currently set into the ELMB are shown in the relevant fields. Please note, that these values may NOT be the values saved into the EEPROM of the ELMB - they are the current settings. If you wish to read the values that are stored in the EEPROM, first Reset the ELMB, and once the bootup message has been received, you may then read the values.

Write - Clicking on the button labeled 'Write' causes the values currently selected in the panel to be written to the ELMB. After clicking this button, you are given a choice whether to save these settings to EEPROM or not. Once the values are saved to the EEPROM (non-volatile memory), they will become the default configuration settings for the ELMB and therefore will still apply even after a Reset NMT command or a Hard Reset (power-off and power-on).

Upon success for either of these operations, some status text is displayed indicating this. If for any reason, a problem occurs, this will also be displayed.

Restrictions
